head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Spitzer Asks Judicial Ethics Chairman To Resign

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Media, Entertainment and Publishing

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Spitzer Asks Judicial Ethics Chairman To Resign

body.head.byline: By DANNY HAKIM; Compiled by John Sullivan

abstract.p: Gov Eliot Spitzer calls on Raoul Felder, celebrity divorce attorney, to step down as chairman of New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct after vote of no confidence by nine other commissioners; members say new book Felder wrote with comedian Jackie Mason repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective; Felder disputes chracterization of book and vows to fight any move to oust him before his term ends in March 2008; photo (S)

block.p: Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on Raoul Felder yesterday to step down as the chairman of a state commission that oversees state and local judges in the wake of a vote of no confidence by the other commissioners last week. Mr. Felder, left, a celebrity divorce lawyer appointed by George E. Pataki, is the chairman of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The other nine members of the commission cast their vote against him last week because they said a new book Mr. Felder wrote with the comedian Jackie Mason ''repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.'' Mr. Felder has disputed the characterization of the book and said he would fight any move to oust him before his term ends next March.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on Raoul Felder yesterday to step down as the chairman of a state commission that oversees state and local judges in the wake of a vote of no confidence by the other commissioners last week. Mr. Felder, left, a celebrity divorce lawyer appointed by George E. Pataki, is the chairman of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The other nine members of the commission cast their vote against him last week because they said a new book Mr. Felder wrote with the comedian Jackie Mason ''repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective.'' Mr. Felder has disputed the characterization of the book and said he would fight any move to oust him before his term ends next March.
